subject: RE: [junit] Testing ugly broken code
msgSnippet: ... I wouldn t recommend fixing code before it s tested, or you ll never know if you are not breaking the code further... -- Cédric http://beust.com/weblog
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> I'm relatively new to JUnit, but I've started to use it a
> bit, and now I'm faced with a project where I think it could
> provide a lot of value. I could use some advice.
>
> Some background: I've come into a project that has no test
> coverage and has some pretty aggregious code...
> meanwhile new features are being slowly added. The thing
> feels like it's on the verge of imploding, and this is the
> calm before the storm.
>
> I'm going through the process right now of adding test cases,
> but as I write them I'm constantly fighting the urge to fix
> stuff. My question: is it better to write all the tests
> first, then go back to fixing what's broken, or to fix the
> bugs and "smelly" code as you go?

I wouldn't recommend fixing code before it's tested, or you'll never know if
you are not breaking the code further...

--
Cédric
http://beust.com/weblog
